articles.title: Orbital Debris and Tracking Challenges
articles.summary: An overview of how space debris impacts satellite tracking and the advanced technology being developed to mitigate associated risks. The article examines the rising problem of orbital debris, its effect on satellite operations, and global initiatives to monitor, predict, and remove hazardous objects. It also covers radar and optical tracking advancements, collision avoidance strategies, and the crucial role of policy in sustaining space activities.

articles.title: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Satellite Boom
articles.summary: The rapid growth of LEO satellites is reshaping connectivity and astronomy. This article examines the surge in launches, the benefits for global internet access, and challenges for astronomers caused by light pollution. It highlights tracking thousands of fast-moving objects, improving collision avoidance, and the need for regulatory measures to manage orbital congestion and ensure safe and sustainable operations in low Earth orbit.

articles.title: How Satellites Are Tracked from Earth
articles.summary: A look into the ground stations, algorithms, and sensors used to track satellites in real time. The article explains how radio antennas and optical telescopes communicate with satellites, enabling accurate tracking and data gathering. It discusses advanced algorithms for orbit prediction, handling vast tracking data, and ensuring precise positioning. It also addresses integrating global sensor networks and tracking in crowded orbits.
